title: Harvey Norman's shortfall helps Gerry Harvey creep up register
text:
Harvey Norman executive chairman Gerry Harvey and other directors marginally increased their stakes after an $8 million shortfall in the retailer's latest capital raising. Nic Walker

Harvey Norman's latest 1-for-17 capital-raise fell $7.8 million short of its $174 million target, despite being issued at an extraordinary 46 per cent discount to the market price during the offer period.

This has been well-canvassed. But one aspect that hasn't been examined is precisely what that shortfall was worth to executive chairman Gerry Harvey. A detail we can now glean from his directors' interest notice, filed on Monday.

Unsurprisingly, Harvey took up his full entitlement to 5.6 million ordinary shares, taking his total direct and indirect holdings to 391.5 million shares. That's 31.42 per cent of the company.

Last month's annual report had him owning 31.34 per cent. So courtesy of some investors not taking up the cheap shares on offer, he's added another 0.08 per cent to his stake. That much of the company, at Harvey Norman's current market capitalisation, would normally cost some $4.1 million.

Had the offer been underwritten, it wouldn't have worked out so advantageously for the company's founder. But doing things the traditional way would mean financial institutions would be the ones creeping up the register. We know how much Gerry hates the thought of that.
description: He's added another 0.08 per cent to his stake, which under normal circumstances would cost $4.1 million.
